result.execSummary:
The defendant Nicholas A. Thorson was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Burglary-Building or Dwelling, a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.10(1m)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  Pay on a regular monthly basis, through probation agent.

If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.    Court advised defendant of the DNA submission requirement and surcharge.
Obtain GED.  Seek and maintain employment commensurate with education objective.

Defendant shall have no contact, directly or indirectly, either personally, by mail, telephone or through any other person, with D.A., or her residence, or the victims and their businesses.

Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and the probation agent. Abide by recommendations, counseling and treatment made by his agent.  

Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.  Sign releases for any outside programming.

Write a letter of apology to the victim, on what defendant did to the victims and how it effected them.  To be pre-approved by his agent.

Obtain housing approved by his agent.

If revoked:  Eligible for the Challenge Incarceration and Substance Abuse programs.
Defendant must attend and successfully complete an acohol assessment, and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.
Defendant must attend and successfully complete a drug assessment, and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

supervisions.notes:

Concurrent with: Jackson County Case No. 14CF200.

superMiscConds.notes: To be paid on a monthly basis through extended supervision.  Outstanding financial obligations shall be collected pursuant to statutory provisions, including deductions from inmate prison monies.  If reconfined or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

Outstanding financial obligations shall be collected pursuant to statutory provisions, including deductions from inmate prison monies.  If reconfined or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.
Obtain and maintain employment, commensurate with his treatment needs.  Not to leave or change employment without prior approval of his agent.

If agent recommends, defendant must attend and successfully complete an alcohol assessment and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant is to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.

Defendant to be subject to random testing by his agent.

If agent recommends, defendant must attend and successfully complete a drug assessment, and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.

Defendant to be subject to random testing by his agent.

Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.  Not to associate with any known illegal drug users or dealers.

Defendant shall have no contact, directly or indirectly, either personally, by mail, telephone or through any other person, or by any other means with the Wazee Sports Center, it's owner or employees.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with extended supervison conditions.

records.addlTxt: Transcript of Sentencing After Revocation, July 6, 2017

DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody, with Attorney Sebion.  Parties have the revocation summary.  No changes or corrections noted.  Victim notification complied with.  State recommended:   14CF188:  4 years initial confinement and 5 years extended supervision.  Total 9 years.  14CF200:  same recommendation, concurrent.   Eligible for CIP and SAR.  Defense recommended:  a condition of extended supervision, treatment court.   2-3 years initial confinement.  Longer extended supervision.  Credit for 504 days in 14CF188.  207 days credit on 14CF200.  

Court ordered:

14CF188:  9 years total.  4  years initial confinement, 5 years extended supervision.  Credit for 505 days.  Judgment for unpaid restitution.  Pay during extended supervision. 

14CF200:  9 years total.  4  years initial confinement, 5 years extended supervision.  Credit for 207 days.  Concurrent.  Judgment for unpaid restitution.  Pay during extended supervision.

Extended supervision conditions:  Seek and maintain employment commensurate with treatment needs.  Not to terminate with out his agent's prior approval.  No contact with victims and their businesses.   Restitution $ Wazee $ Parkland.  AODA.    Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.  Eligible for Challenge and Substance abuse programs.    The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.  CC.
From Nikki Hoyer
Sentencing hearing on revocation on July 6, 2017 at 10:30 am.
And Revocation Summary (routed to Judge and C.O.)
From DOC along with Revocation Packet
School attendance record.

DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person, without counsel.  Court questioned defendant on whether he reapplied for SPD representation.  He did not.  Attorney Fox addressed probation's letter with the court.  Probation Agent K.G. was present and addressed the court.  S. H., Director of Special Education services at BRF school district also appeared.  She addressed the court.  5 credits short to graduate.  Defendant has attended less than 50% of school days.  Defendant made a short statement.  Court spoke to the defendant.  Comply or be revoked.

records.addlTxt:
DA Gerald Fox appears for the State.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody, with Attorney Rivard.  Parties have reviewed the PSI are ready to proceed.  State recommends:  Probation 5 years, 9 mo jail 14CF188 only. Seek and maintain employment.  Complete HSED.  Pay restitution.  Remain in home and follow their rules.  No contact with any victims.  LOA to the victims, pre-approved by agent.  Discussion held on amount of restitution.  Victim notification complied with, per State.  Defense recommends:  3 years probation.  297 days credit.  State stipulates to the credit.  Defendant elected to exercise his right to allocution.  

Court ordered:  Sentence withheld, 5 years probation.  Seek and maintain employment commensurate with education needs.  Obtain GED.  Abide by recommendations, counseling and treatment made by agent.  Sign releases for any outside programming, so that the agent can monitor his progress.  No contact with D.A., or her residence. No contact with victims and their businesses.  Write a letter of apology to the victims, to be preapproved by his agent.  What did I do to the victim.  Restitution $2531.72 Wazee $600.00 Parkland.  Payable monthly.  AODA.    Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.  297 days jail, credit for 297 days. Obtain housing approved by his agent.  CC.   Court advised defendant of the DNA submission requirement and surcharge.  If revoked: Eligible for CIP & SAP.
letter of support
Restitution worksheet.
Sentencing hearing at 08-18-2015 03:30 pm

DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person from the jail, with Attorney Rivard.  Defendant plead no contest to amended count 1.  Counts 2-5 dismissed and read in for restitution purposes.  Victim rights notification complied with.  Court questioned the state regarding the amount of restitution.  DA Fox gave approximate amounts.  Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, elements and constitutional rights waived with the defendant.  Defendant stated he understood, no threats or promises made.  Felony warnings given.  Defense stipulated to a factual basis.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the defendant's plea.  The plea was entered, and constitutional rights were waived freely, voluntarily and intelligently.  Found guilty of amended Count. 1.  PSI ordered.  Due by July 24, 2015.  1 hour sentencing hearing to be scheduled.  Court requested that if any written statements were to be considered at sentencing, they should be filed before the sentencing date.
Sentencing hearing at 08-18-2015 03:30 pm
DA Gerald Fox appears for the State by telephone.  Attorney Rivard appeared by telephone.  Defendant did not appear.  Trial for tomorrow is canceled.  Plea set for 9:00 am.

DA Gerald Fox appears for the State.  Defendant appeared by video from the Jail.  Attorney Rivard appeared by telephone.  Parties are ready for trial on 14CF188 and 14CF190.  5/22/15 final date to settle.
State's

from defendant's mother.

Pre-trial conference at 02-04-2015 10:00 am.

Defendant appeared in custody from JASO with counsel Francis Rivard.  Melissa Inlow appeared for the State.  Colloquy done for waiver of right to preliminary hearing.
